A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO 3 - occurs in?

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Bicarbonate Mechanism
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules. H + secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO 3 – forming carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell. In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + . Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids. Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H + .
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules.
  • ➤ H + secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO 3 – forming carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell.
  • ➤ In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + .
  • ➤ Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.
  • ➤ Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H + .

He has had a history of hypertension for ten years. His blood pressure is recorded as 190/110mmhg; his pulse pressure is 90 mmHg. Which of the following parameters explains this high pulse pressure in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Definition

Formula

Arterial Compliance

Absolute change in vessel diameter according to change in applied pressure

Difference between diastolic and systolic diameter (ΔD) / difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure (ΔP)

Arterial distensibility

The relative change in vessel diameter according to change in applied pressure

ΔD/(ΔP× vessel diameter in the diastolic phase (D)) in mmHg

Elastic modulus index

Alteration of pressure necessary for theoretical stretch from resting vessel diameter

(ΔP×D) /ΔD in mm Hg

b - Stiffness index

The ratio of the natural logarithm of systolic/diastolic pressure to relative change in diameter

log(SBP/DBP)/(△D/D)

Pulse wave velocity (PWV)

The speed of the pulse wave extends through the length of the vessel

Stiffness index × diastolic blood pressure/ (2× blood density) When the blood density is assumed to be 1.050 g/cm3.

The parents describe that the boy has had multiple infections over the past few years. The doctor decides to order a Nitroblue tetrazolium test . For which of the immune cell assessment is this test used?

A 9-year-old boy, while riding a bicycle, was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs ; he was rushed to a nearby hospital, injection tetanus toxoid was administered, and wound cleaning and dressing were done. Which of the following is the best statement regarding the given pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage

options.label: B
options.text: Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules

options.label: C
options.text: Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage

options.label: D
options.text: In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury

questions.correct_answer: B. Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules
questions.explanation:
Swelling
  • Swelling is a cardinal sign of inflammation.
  • It is a hallmark of acute inflammation and is caused by increased permeability of post-capillary venules due to increased inter endothelial spaces.
  • Transcytosis is the increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cells into interstitial space, contributing to swelling.
  • Histamine is a chemical mediator that plays a pivotal role in transcytosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a burn injury to his hands. He is vitally stable. He does not have any significant medical history. Over a few weeks, the burned skin heals without requiring skin grafting. Which of the following is the most critical factor responsible for rapid healing?
questions.explanation:
Primary Intention

Clean wound with limited tissue loss Wounds edges easily approximated Classic surgical wound closure Using suture, staples, adhesive tape

Secondary Intention

Large tissue loss / heavy contamination Wound cleaned & left open to granulate Surgeon may pack & place drain Wound care q day promotes granulation

Tertiary Intention

Also called: Delayed primary closure Often used with heavy bacteria counts Wound is cleaned, debrided, left open Typically 4-5 days-then surgical closure

A 45-year-old male patient, an already diagnosed case of chronic congestive heart failure , is currently on medication. While reviewing medications, you notice that the patient is taking eplerenone. Which of the following is the clinical indication of eplerenone in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Able to cause hypokalemia in predisposed patients

questions.correct_answer: C. It reduces myocardial perfusion defect
questions.explanation:
Eplerenone
  • It is an aldosterone antagonist
  • It is used as a potassium-sparing diuretic and can cause hyperkalemia
  • It can reduce mortality by reducing myocardial perfusion defects after myocardial infarction.
  • It does not cause gynecomastia because it does not bind to androgen and progesterone receptors.

 

Eplerenone, a selective aldosterone receptor antagonist, has been found to reduce myocardial perfusion defects by several mechanisms:

  1. Aldosterone blockade: Eplerenone selectively blocks the aldosterone receptor, inhibiting the effects of aldosterone on the heart and blood vessels. Aldosterone promotes myocardial fibrosis, vascular inflammation, and endothelial dysfunction, which can lead to impaired myocardial perfusion. By blocking aldosterone, eplerenone helps to prevent these adverse effects.

  2. Vasodilation: Eplerenone promotes vasodilation by reducing vasoconstrictor tone in the coronary arteries and improving blood flow to the myocardium. This vasodilatory effect helps to alleviate myocardial perfusion defects by increasing the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the heart muscle.

  3. Anti-inflammatory effects: Eplerenone has been shown to possess anti-inflammatory properties, which can help reduce inflammation and oxidative stress within the coronary arteries. This anti-inflammatory action contributes to improving myocardial perfusion by reducing the vascular inflammation that can impair blood flow.

questions.text: What medication is recommended for a 55-year-old female presenting to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of progressive shortness of breath, chest tightness, and a 2-month history of intermittent nonproductive cough? The patient, a former smoker with a history of cardiovascular disease and current propranolol use, is anxious, unable to speak in full sentences, and works at a cattle ranch.
questions.explanation:
Drug Class Example Drugs Mechanism of Action
Short-Acting Beta-Agonists (SABAs) Albuterol, Levalbuterol Stimulate beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the airways, leading to bronchodilation and relaxation of smooth muscles.
Long-Acting Beta-Agonists (LABAs) Salmeterol, Formoterol Similar to SABAs, but have a longer duration of action. Used for long-term control and combined with other asthma medications.
Inhaled Corticosteroids Fluticasone, Budesonide Reduce inflammation in the airways by suppressing immune response and inhibiting the release of inflammatory mediators.
Leukotriene Modifiers Montelukast, Zafirlukast Block the action of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory molecules that can cause airway constriction and mucus production.
Long-Acting Muscarinic Antagonists (LAMAs) Tiotropium, Umeclidinium Block muscarinic receptors, leading to bronchodilation by relaxing smooth muscles in the airways.
Combination Inhalers Fluticasone/Salmeterol, Budesonide/Formoterol Contain both a corticosteroid to reduce inflammation and a LABA to open airways, providing both anti-inflammatory and bronchodilator effects.
Monoclonal Antibodies Omalizumab, Mepolizumab, Benralizumab Target specific immune molecules involved in asthma, reducing inflammation and decreasing the frequency of exacerbations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was among the 6 people who succumbed to the injuries sustained during a bus stand grenade blast. An autopsy of his body would reveal the characteristic features of the Marshal's triad except?

questions.explanation:
S.228 A IPC
  • Disclosure of the identity of the victim of certain offences like 376, section 376A, 376B, 376C or 376D
  • Printing or publication of a proceeding without prior permission of the court

2 Years + fine

S.354 IPC
  • Assault or use of criminal force on to a woman with intent to outrage her modesty
  • Cognizable, non-bailable
  • Eg. Stripping naked a female patient for medical examination
  • A female patient can accuse a male doctor of indecent assault (intimate touching or fondling the breast or private parts etc.) during the consultation

1 to 5 years + fine

S.354-A IPC
  • Sexual harassment is defined as physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures or demanding sexual favours, showing pornography against her will or making sexually coloured remarks
  • The offence is cognizable and bailable

It is punishable with (rigorous) imprisonment for 1–3 years with/ without a fine

S.354 C IPC
  • Voyeurism: Any man who watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed either by the perpetrator or by any other person

First 1 to 3 yrs + fine

Second 3 to 7 yrs + fine

S.493 IPC
  • A man by deceit causes a woman not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit with him in that belief
  • Non-cognizable, non-bailable

10 Years + fine

Culture Club frontman Boy George described a bad trip in his 1995 autobiography, "Take It Like a Man." George got bored waiting after taking the first tab and took a second dose, so when the drug finally took effect, the trip was very intense. It can take anywhere from 30 to 90 minutes to start feeling the effects. These effects can last up to 12 hours, depending on how much you've taken. George and his friends headed to a club. After going through feelings of paranoia about the police presence outside the club, and upsetting another celebrity, George began to feel that he had lost control of his body. The visual hallucinations made it feel like "everything was breathing and coming at me. I started shrinking and feeling scared. We had to leave." He upset most of his companions, who left him with his pal Marilyn. By then, George had lost control of his bodily functions. "I was tripping so badly I couldn't get myself to the toilet. Marilyn led me to the loo in hysterics and left me staring at the bowl. I caught my melting face in the mirror and started to freak. 'I can't go, I can't' [then] I pissed myself." Bad trips are characteristically associated with the addiction of :

questions.text: What is the composition of the gallstones given below?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcium oxalate + calcium phosphate + calcium stearate

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate

options.label: C
options.text: Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium carbonate

questions.correct_answer: B. Calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate
questions.explanation:
Gallstones
Cholesterol stones Pigmented stones                 
  • In the USA and Europe, 80% are cholesterol or mixed stones
  • Cholesterol or mixed stones - 51-99% pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments and phospholipids
  • In Asia, 80% are pigment stones
  • Pigmented stones contain <20% of cholesterol and are dark because of the presence of calcium bilirubinate
  • Black stones - Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
  • Brown pigment stones- calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate + cholesterol
  • Pigment stones are often radiopaque
  • β-glucuronidase secreted by bacteria that enzymatically cleaves conjugated bilirubin to produce the insoluble unconjugated bilirubin, which then precipitates with calcium, and along with dead bacterial cell bodies forms soft brownstones in the biliary tree.
  • Brownstones occur due to parasitic infection with Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm) or Clonorchis sinesis (liver fluke)

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted for appetite loss, nausea, and back p ain . A physical examination revealed right hypochondriac tenderness and obvious jaundice . MRCP revealed dilated intrahepatic and common hepatic bile ducts, distended gallbladder, and erosion of less than 1/3 of the circumference of common hepatic duct. What is the best next step in the management?

I Extrinsic compression of the common bile duct by an impacted gallstone
II Cholecystobiliary fistula secondary to an eroded gallstone involving one third of the circumference of the common bile duct
III Cholecystobiliary fistula involving two thirds of the circumference of the common bile duct
IV Cholecystobiliary fistula comprising the whole circumference of the common bile duct
V Any type plus a cholecystoenteric fistula
Va Without gallstone ileus
Vb With gallstone ileus

Types Treatment
Type I Partial cholecystectomy
Type II & III Partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage
Type IV & V Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis

Decreases risk

A 50-year-old male has been admitted to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain and distension for the past 2 hours. He also complains of low-grade fever and weight loss for the past 4 weeks. A diagnosis of intestinal obstruction is made secondary to tuberculosis. The patient is taken to the operating theatre for the laparotomy under general anaesthesia. Which of the following component is least likely essential to provide optimal surgical conditions?
questions.explanation:
Stage I

Analgesia state: Patient is conscious and rational, with decreased perception of pain

Stage II

Delirium stage: Patient is unconscious; body responds reflexively; irregular breathing pattern with breath holding.

Stage III

Surgical anesthesia: Increasing degree of muscle relaxation; unable to protect airway.

Stage IV

Medullary depression: There is depression of cardiovascular and respiratory centers

Stage of Anesthetic Depth Clinical Characteristics Respiratory Function Cardiovascular Function Eye Reflexes Purpose
Stage 1: Analgesia Conscious, fully awake, normal reflexes. Unaffected or slightly increased rate. Normal or slightly increased rate. Present Pre-induction, calming, pre-operative.
Stage 2: Delirium Excitement, irregular respiration, increased muscle tone. Irregular, shallow, increased rate. Increased, bounding pulse. Absent or erratic To be avoided, transition quickly to Stage 3.
Stage 3: Surgical Anesthesia Smooth anesthesia, regular respiration, muscle relaxation. Regular, moderate rate, adequate depth. Normal, slightly decreased rate. Absent, central fixation Main surgical stage, controlled anesthesia.
Plane 1: Light Anesthesia Initial stage of surgical anesthesia, reflexes return. Regular, normal rate. Normal. Absent, central fixation For minor procedures, limited stimulation.
Plane 2: Moderate Anesthesia Adequate surgical anesthesia, optimal reflexes. Regular, normal rate. Normal. Absent, central fixation For most surgical procedures.
Plane 3: Deep Anesthesia Excessive depth, reflexes absent or greatly depressed. Regular, slow rate. Slowed. Absent Risk of respiratory depression, to be avoided.
Stage 4: Medullary Paralysis Severe overdose, critical depression of vital centers. Slow, shallow, irregular rate. Bradycardia, possible cardiac arrest. Absent Life-threatening, requires immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer was brought to the Emergency departmen t by an ambulance. He had a boxing match prior to his arrival. A 21-year-old male presents to the emergency ward complaining of vomiting and epigastric pain radiating to the back for 2 days. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and Hashimoto thyroiditis. His only medication is levothyroxine. He drinks 1–2 beers on the weekends and occasionally smokes marijuana. The patient appears distressed and is diaphoretic. The patient is vitally stable. A 44-year-old female presents to her family physician complaining of a burning sensation during urination and pain in flank. On physical examination, she has slight fever. A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 2 years despite regular intercourse with her husband twice weekly. Menarche occurs at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. She is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation in this patient is expected to occur how many hours after an LH surge is demonstrated?
questions.explanation:
Menstrual Cycle Phase Duration Hormonal Changes Events
Menstrual Phase 3-7 days Low estrogen and progesterone Shedding of the endometrial lining; menstrual bleeding occurs
Follicular Phase 7-21 days Increasing estrogen levels Follicles in the ovaries mature, preparing to release an egg
    Low progesterone levels Uterine lining begins to thicken
Ovulation 1-2 days Surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) and estrogen Release of a mature egg (ovum) from the ovary
Luteal Phase 10-16 days Increased progesterone levels The uterine lining continues to thicken, preparing for potential embryo implantation
    Elevated estrogen levels If pregnancy does not occur, hormones begin to decline
Premenstrual Phase 2-10 days Declining estrogen and progesterone PMS symptoms may occur, and the endometrial lining is shed if fertilization did not happen

This is most likely indicative of which one of the following conditions?

A 30-year-old P2L2 woman with previous 2 vaginal deliveries presents for a routine pap smear. She complains of occasional mucoid vaginal discharge and no other significant complaints. On per speculum examination, the cervical os is expected to appear:

An 8-year-old child presents with short stature and some abnormalities of the hand and pelvis. His hands are like a trident, and his pelvis is no more than champagne glass pelvis. On examination, his vision is normal, and there is no history of bleeding diathesis. He has not been taking any medicine for any disease. Based on laboratory investigation, his serum cortisol and calcium levels are in the normal range. His father is 50 years old, his mother is 35, and both have proportionate short stature. The physician suspects a genetic disorder. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this condition?
At what age will a child achieve the milestone shown in the image below ?
questions.explanation:
4 months

grasps a rattle when placed in the hand

4 -6months

mouthing of objects

6 months

Unidextrous or palmar grasp

6-7 months

Transfer objects from 1 hand to another

7 months

palmar grasp

9 months

immature/ assisted pincer grasp

12 months

Mature/unassisted pincer grasp

'Casting'

questions.text: A pre-term baby, born at 30 weeks of gestation, has been admitted to the nursery. On examination, he has a low body weight, chest pain due to respiratory distress syndrome, and a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. He is being nursed in an incubator. The consultant has advised keeping the environmental temperature in a range at which the baby's basal metabolic rate (BMR) is at a minimum, oxygen consumption is at least, and the baby maintains its normal body temperature. What is this environment called?

A 35-year-old female with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus delivers a term baby weighing 3980 grams . She has used her insulin regularly throughout the pregnancy. The image of the physical examination of the newborn is shown. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in further investigations of this baby ?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased risk of congenital heart diseases

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased risk of congenital heart diseases

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy to the primary care provider complaining that the child has become irritable, looks dull and weak, and has also lost weight. On examination, edema is absent, his appetite is good, and there is no liver enlargement, but his skin and hair are thin . He also has bradycardia and hypothermia. His mid-upper arm circumference is low, and his body mass index is low. The socio-economic status of the family is also poor . What is the child probably suffering from?

A 12-year-old boy with type-1 diabetes and congenital right renal agenesis comes to the ER with palpitations and chest pain. Despite OTC meds, the pain persists, preceded by muscle weakness and cramps for two days. An ECG shows signs of hyperkalemia, leading to cardiac arrest . After resuscitation, he was admitted for hyperkalemia management. Nursing is instructed to monitor potassium and ECGs daily. Potassium levels over four days are 9.1, 7.7, 6.6, and 5.5 mmol/L . What ECG changes should be expected on these days?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves → Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves

options.label: B
options.text: Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves

options.label: C
options.text: Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Sine wave pattern → Peaked T waves

options.label: D
options.text: Peaked T waves → Prolonged PR interval → Absent P waves → Sine wave pattern

questions.correct_answer: B. Sine wave pattern → Absent P waves → Prolonged PR interval → Peaked T waves
questions.explanation:
Potassium level (mmol/L)

Mechanism

ECG changes

5.5-6.5

Repolarisation abnormalities

Peaked T waves

6.5-7.0

Progressive atrial paralysis

P wave widening/flattening

PR prolongation

P wave eventually disappear

7.0-9.0

Conduction abnormalities

Bradyarrhythmias: Sinus bradycardia; high-grade AV block with slow junctional and ventricular escape rhythms; slow AF Conduction blocks (bundle branch block, fascicular blocks) Prolonged QRS interval with bizarre QRS morphology

>9.0

All of above

Development of sine wave appearance (pre-terminal rhythm)

Asystole

Ventricular fibrillation

PEA with bizarre, wide complex rhythm

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to diarrhea and irritability for several weeks . The mother tells the pediatrician that the child develops these symptoms only after drinking milk and eating a meal with yogurt . Which of the following is not a feature of this child's condition ?

A neonate presented with generalised cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body and hypoplasia of all limbs . An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy . An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis . Which of these tests is most likely to show a positive result in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Congenital Infections

                              Physical findings

Varicella Zoster virus
  • Cicatrizing skin lesions
  • Hypoplasia of all limbs
  • Chorioretinitis

Cytomegalovirus
  • Intrauterine growth retardation
  • Microcephaly
  • Periventricular calcifications
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Prolonged neonatal jaundice
  • Generalized blue–purple macular rash

Toxoplasma
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Diffuse cerebral calcifications.

Rubella
  • Cataract
  • Deafness (Sensorineural hearing loss)
  • Congenital heart disease (Patent ductus arteriosus)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of ringing and pulsating sensation in his left ear. The patient also has a history of progressive hearing loss for 1 year. Endoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. Further examination reveals conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is correct about the muscle involved in patient's pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Tensor tympani is derived from 1 st branchial arch

options.label: B
options.text: Stapedius muscle is derived from 1 st branchial arch

options.label: C
options.text: The facial nerve supplies the tensor tympani muscle

options.label: D
options.text: The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies stapedius muscle

questions.correct_answer: A. Tensor tympani is derived from 1 st branchial arch

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient ward with complaints of hearing loss, facial weakness, reduced facial sensations, fever, headache, and double vision for 2 weeks. The patient has diabetes mellitus and uses insulin. On physical examination, the patient is hypertensive. A suspected diagnosis of Gradenigo’s syndrome was made. Which of the following cranial nerve is involved in the discussed case:

A 9-year-old child presents to the ENT department with complaints of recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing for one year. The patient is vitally stable. On further investigation, tympanometry showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type Implications
Type A Normal tympanogram/sensorineural hearing loss where conductive mechanism is normal.
Type B Flat curve, no change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in fluid in the middle ear.
Type C Maximum compliance in negative pressure. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction.
Type As Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
Type Ad High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the ENT outpatient department with a whistling sound while breathing for the past 3 months. He reports that a large crust develops over his septum. Due to irritation, he tried to peel it off, leading to nose bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?

A 50-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice and neck swelling for the past few months. He mentions that the neck swelling increases on playing an instrument. Which of the following statement is incorrect ? 1) Gradual onset of stridor 2) Neck swelling that is soft and compressible 3) On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound 4) Seen in professional trumpet players, glass blowers

A 3-year-old, well-immunized boy was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of sore throat, high-grade fever, and noisy breathing with an inability to swallow for the past four hours. The physical examination showed a toxic, tachypnoeic child with inspiratory stridor. There is suprasternal, supraclavicular, and intercostal recession during inspiration . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old male presents to the clinic due to a sore throat and fever for 4 days . It is associated with right earache and headache. He denies cough or nasal discharge. On physical examination, the tonsils are congested and swollen . Which of the following nerve is involved in referring the pain to the right ear?

A final year medical student is studying the nerve supply of the larynx before assisting a surgeon in thyroidectomy. He notes that the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent laryngeal are mainly responsible for the nerve supply of the larynx . Which of the following statements regarding the nerve supply of the larynx is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: External laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid.

options.label: C
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve takes part in Galen’s anastomosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Internal laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.

questions.correct_answer: D. Internal laryngeal nerve gives sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords.
questions.explanation:
Muscles of the larynx  
  Innervation Action
Cricothyroid External laryngeal nerve Tenses vocal cords and increases the pitch of the voice.
Thyroarytenoid Inferior laryngeal nerve (the terminal part of the recurrent laryngeal nerve) Relaxes vocal cords and lowers the pitch of the voice.
Posterior cricoarytenoid Abducts the vocal cords.
Lateral cricoarytenoid Adducts the vocal cords.
Transverse and oblique arytenoids Adducts the vocal cords.
Vocalis Adjust the tension of the vocal cords during phonation.

questions.text: When light rays travel through various mediums, they undergo a physical phenomenon known as refraction. The same thing happens when light travels through the eye. Which of the following structures in the human eye has the highest refractive power ?

A 35-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of blurry vision, photophobia, and watering eyes for one week. He has no history of smoking or drinking. The vitals are in the normal range. The eyes are red, and there is epiphora on physical examination. Which of the following is the best treatment for this given condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Elschnig’s operation:

Type of ectropion

Surgeries

Congenital ectropion

For moderate to severe cases -horizontal lid tightening

Involutional ectropion (the most common type of ectropion)
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty
  • Horizontal lid shortening
  • Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski Operation
  • Lateral tarsal strip procedure

Paralytic ectropion

Often resolves spontaneously;

For non-resolving cases-

  • Horizontal lid tightening

Cicatricial ectropion
  • V-Y operation
  • Z-plasty (Elschnig’s operation).

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?

A 27-year-old male carpenter presents to the emergency department with complaints of redness in the left eye after being hit by a flying iron chip while working on an iron statue 2 hours ago. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is vitally stable. On examination, there was a puncture in the anterior capsule with focal anterior subcapsular opacity, and a temporal intraventricular metallic foreign body was found. Which of the following investigation is contraindicated in the patient’s current pathology?

Keratitis is an inflammation of the cornea — the clear, dome-shaped tissue on the front of your eye that covers the pupil and iris. Keratitis may or may not be associated with an infection. The following image shows which disease?

A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his eyes. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with Xerophthalmia secondary to vitamin A deficiency. Which of the following is the first primary sign, first secondary sign and characteristic finding, respectively, seen in patients of Xeropthalmia?

options.label: A
options.text: Night blindness, Conjunctival xerosis & Bitots spots

options.label: B
options.text: Corneal xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots

options.label: C
options.text: Night blindness, Corneal xerosis & Bitots spots

options.label: D
options.text: Conjunctival xerosis, Night blindness & Bitots spots

questions.correct_answer: A. Night blindness, Conjunctival xerosis & Bitots spots

Correct Option A - Night blindness, Conjunctival xerosis & B

XN

Night blindness in children

X1A

Conjuctival xerosis

X1B

Bitot’s spts

Corneal xerosis

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia < 1/3 corneal surface

X3B

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia ≥ 1/3 corneal surface

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to an outdoor ophthalmology department with a history of severe dull pain and redness of both eyes for the last two days. She also complains of discomfort in both eyes while driving at night. A typical butterfly rash on the face spares nasolabial folds on physical examination. Upon further inquiry, the ophthalmologist knows she is a known case of SLE and taking Hydroxychloroquine . The ophthalmologist counsels her that she is suffering from scleritis, which is the inflammation of the white of the eye. Concerning the anatomy, the sclera is the thinnest and thickest, respectively, at which part of the eyeball?

options.label: A
options.text: Under insertion of recti & Posterior pole of the eye

options.label: B
options.text: At the limbus & Posterior pole of the eye

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior to attachment of rectus & at the limbus

options.label: D
options.text: At the equator & Anterior to attachment of the rectus

questions.correct_answer: A. Under insertion of recti & Posterior pole of the eye

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl baby is brought in by her parents to the ophthalmology outdoor clinic for the evaluation of esotropia . Her parents noted that the baby's eyes started to turn inwards shortly after birth and that her condition worsened . They also pointed out that this worsens when she is tired , and she alternates between the right eye and the left eye. She is suspected to be a case of essential infantile esotropia. Which of the following is the feature of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Surgery can be done anytime, irrespective of the time passed

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - A

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the dermatologic clinic with the complaint of hair loss for the past few weeks. He states that his hair loss is painless. On examination, patchy hair loss is observed on the scalp as shown below: The exclamation mark sign is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-month-old male child presents to the clinic accompanied by his mother with a rash, as shown in the picture below. The rash started appearing on his trunk this morning, and the mother believes it is spreading to his arms and legs. He has a history of high-grade fever and a seizure three days back. At that time, his work-up was normal, and he was sent home with acetaminophen and fluids. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old patient presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 1 week. Examination shows multiple, well-demarcated, oval, finely scaling hypopigmented patches over the trunk. 10% KOH mount shows spaghetti and meatball appearance. Which of the following signs is commonly seen in association with this disease?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic signs Associated conditions
Iris sign Erythema multiforme
Auspitz sign Psoriasis
Coup D’ongle sign Pityriasis versicolor
Darier sign Urticaria pigmentosa

On examination, small hypopigmented scaly macules with intact sensations are found on the cheek. The rest of the body is spared. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
